summary: This is a legal memorandum filed by Ghislaine Maxwell's defense team, arguing to suppress evidence obtained via a grand jury subpoena to the law firm Boies Schiller Flexner LLP and to dismiss perjury counts (Five and Six) based on her 2016 civil deposition transcripts. The motion alleges the government made false statements to Judge McMahon to circumvent a protective order from the Giuffre v. Maxwell defamation case, violating due process.

persons.name: Ghislaine Maxwell
persons.context: The defendant in the criminal case, moving to suppress evidence from her civil depositions and dismiss perjury counts. Her 2016 depositions are central to the motion.

persons.name: Jeffrey S. Pagliuca
persons.context: Attorney for Ghislaine Maxwell, listed as counsel on the memorandum.

persons.name: Laura A. Menninger
persons.context: Attorney for Ghislaine Maxwell, listed as counsel on the memorandum.

persons.name: Mark S. Cohen
persons.context: Attorney for Ghislaine Maxwell, listed as counsel on the memorandum.

persons.name: Christian R. Everdell
persons.context: Attorney for Ghislaine Maxwell, listed as counsel on the memorandum. Signed the certificate of service.

persons.name: Bobbi C. Stemheim
persons.context: Attorney for Ghislaine Maxwell, listed as counsel on the memorandum.

persons.name: Virginia Giuffre
persons.context: Referred to as 'Giuffre' in the text. She was the plaintiff in the defamation case Giuffre v. Maxwell, which led to the depositions at issue.

persons.name: David Boies
persons.context: Named partner of Boies Schiller Flexner LLP. The motion alleges he approached the government in summer 2016 urging a perjury investigation of Maxwell.

persons.name: Jeffrey Epstein
persons.context: Deceased financier. The civil case was described as a 'proxy prosecution' of him. The government's investigation was initially into him.

persons.name: Judge McMahon
persons.context: Chief Judge who presided over the government's ex parte application to modify the protective order. The motion alleges she was misled by the government.

persons.name: Judge Netburn
persons.context: Magistrate Judge who rejected a similar government request in a different civil case (Jane Doe 43 v. Epstein), criticizing the ex parte tactic.

persons.name: AUSA
persons.context: Assistant U.S. Attorney who made representations to Judge McMahon. The motion alleges these representations about lack of contact with Boies Schiller were false.

connections.description: Maxwell was the defendant in Giuffre's defamation lawsuit, which resulted in the depositions central to the perjury counts.
The document references Maxwell's knowledge of Epstein's activities and her own relationship with him, which was a subject of the civil depositions.
The motion alleges the law firm had contact with and urged the U.S. Attorney's Office to investigate Maxwell/Epstein prior to the subpoena, contradicting government statements to the court.
Boies's firm represented Giuffre against Maxwell and, according to the motion, actively sought a criminal perjury prosecution against Maxwell.
Pagliuca is listed as defense counsel for Maxwell in this criminal case.

events.title: Maxwell's First Deposition
events.description: Ghislaine Maxwell gave a deposition in Giuffre v. Maxwell, relying on the protective order. Her answers here form the basis for Count Five (perjury).

events.title: Maxwell's Second Deposition
events.description: Maxwell gave a second, more extensive deposition covering intimate sexual details, ordered by the court citing the protective order. Her answers here form the basis for Count Six (perjury).

events.title: Boies Schiller Meets with AUSA
events.description: Attorneys from Boies Schiller met with an AUSA and 'urged [the office] to open an investigation of Epstein and Maxwell.'

events.title: David Boies Approaches Government
events.description: David Boies approached the government asking 'if the Southern District would consider charging Maxwell with perjury' based on the deposition transcripts.

events.title: First Hearing Before Judge McMahon
events.description: Government argued ex parte for modification of the protective order, claiming ignorance of the contents of Boies Schiller's files.

events.title: Second Hearing Before Judge McMahon
events.description: Judge McMahon specifically questioned the government about pre-subpoena contacts with Boies Schiller. The AUSA allegedly gave false assurances of no prior contact.

events.title: Judge McMahon Modifies Protective Order
events.description: Judge McMahon granted the government's application, allowing Boies Schiller to comply with the grand jury subpoena, based on the government's representations.

events.title: Judge Netburn Rejects Government Request
events.description: Magistrate Judge Netburn rejected an identical government ex parte request in Jane Doe 43 v. Epstein, criticizing the attempt to circumvent the protective order.

events.title: Filing of Suppression Motion
events.description: Maxwell's defense team files this memorandum in support of motion to suppress evidence from Boies Schiller and dismiss perjury counts.

locations: Southern District of New York (court jurisdiction)
Palm Beach house (referenced as a location where activities occurred)
Denver, CO (location of Haddon, Morgan & Foreman P.C.)
New York, NY (location of Cohen & Gresser LLP and Law Offices of Bobbi C. Stemheim)
keyFacts: The motion seeks to suppress all evidence obtained from Boies Schiller Flexner LLP via grand jury subpoena and to dismiss perjury Counts Five and Six, which are based on Maxwell's 2016 civil deposition transcripts.

It alleges the government made false statements to Judge McMahon, claiming no prior contact with Boies Schiller and that the firm did not 'foment' the investigation, when in fact the firm had urged prosecution as early as February 2016.
A protective order in Giuffre v. Maxwell, which lacked a 'law enforcement exception,' was secretly modified via an ex parte proceeding after the government's alleged misrepresentations.
Maxwell's defense argues she relied on this protective order's confidentiality to answer intimate questions in her depositions instead of invoking the Fifth Amendment.

The motion references a contrasting ruling by Magistrate Judge Netburn, who rejected a similar government tactic in a related case, noting the government was trying to 'side-step' protections by subpoenaing a 'willing (and perhaps eager)' party.
